fields.description: [Containment] If the error has effect on a particular feature of an application, temporarily disable that feature.
[Containment] Make a backup of the data to prevent the propagation of the error.
[Remediation] Remove all altered content and replace it with the legitimate content, restored from earlier backup. Make sure this content is free from  vulnerabilities.
[Recovery] Restart the stopped services.
[Recovery] Ensure that the impacted services are reachable again.
[Recovery] Ensure that your infrastructure performance is back to your baseline performance.
[Containment] Identify the threat tied with blackmail (denial of service, disclosure of sensitive datas on internet, disclosure of private datas, block your datas access, phishing using the brand)
[Containment] Check for other similar blackmailing attempts
[Containment] Check and collect all technical datas related to the blackmail
[Containment] Search for anyone having interest in threatening the company
[Containment] Attempt to identify the blackmail's source
[Containment] Attempt to find how the attacker got into the system and/or how he got the sensitive datas
[Containment] Contact local law enforcement with proof of what he threaten
[Containment] Buy time from the fraudster
[Remediation] Ignore the blackmail and set up appropriate watch to detect and react to any follow-up
[Remediation] Don't take remediation measures alone and contact the appropriate department
[Recovery] Notify the top management of any decision/action taken
[Containment] If a particular feature of an application is targeted, just disable that feature.
[Containment] Try to block the DDOS flow as early in the network as possible (via the router, the FW).
[Containment] Terminate unwanted TCP session.
[Containment] Blackhole DDoS traffic targeting the original IP addresses.
[Containment] Communicate thanks to another comminucation channel (mail server, web server, ...).
[Containment] Set up filter to avoid response trafic to the attack.
[Remediation] Contact your ISP and make sure that it enforces remediation measures.
[Recovery] Ensure that the impacted services are reachable again.
[Recovery] Ensure that your infrastructure performance is back to your baseline performance.
[Containment] Disconnect the industrial network from the IT network
[Containment] Pass the industrial process in manual mode
[Containment] Isolate the industrial process impacted : use firewall/IPS rules to block the attack
[Remediation] Change the PLC password : use the industrial laptop programming
[Remediation] Read the PLC logs to identify the source of the attack : Program Modifications
[Remediation] Check all PLC program of the industrial network
[Remediation] Check all PC connected on the industrial network : SCADA network (see WindowsIntrusion)
[Remediation] Check if there is no unauthorized device connected on the industrial network use : read the switch logs
[Remediation] Check if there is no unauthorized people on the the industrial process
[Recovery] Restore the offline PLC backup program
[Recovery] Block unwanted connection
[Containment] Notify the management, legal and public relation team to make sure they are prepared to deal with an identity theft.
[Containment] Notify the targeted employee and anyone he can work with: coworkers, clients, partners.
[Containment] Change employee password if some were stolen / used.
[Remediation] Legal team should file a claim if the employee is targeted as part of the company or the employee should file a claim himself if he is personally targeted outside the work context.
[Recovery] Renew some official documents like ID card if those document were physically stolen.
[Recovery] Legal team should file a claim if the employee is targeted as part of the company or the employee should file a claim himself if he is personally targeted outside the work context.
[Containment] Objective: Mitigate the attack’s effects on the targeted environment.
[Containment] Notify the management, legal and Public Relations team to make sure they are prepared to deal with a massive or targeted disclosure.
[Containment] Depending on the leakage vector, block the access to the disclosure URI, the disclosure server, the disclosure source or the disclosure recipients.
[Containment] This action must be done on all infrastructure points.
[Containment] Suspend the logical and physical credentials of the insider if the leakage has been confirmed.
[Containment] Involve Humans Resources and legal team before any action.
[Containment] Isolate the computing system (desktop, printer) used to disclose data in order to perform a forensic analysis later.
[Containment] This manipulation should be done the hard way: remove the electric plug (and the battery in case of a laptop).
[Remediation] Objective: Take actions to remove the threat and avoid future incidents.
[Remediation] If data has been sent to public servers, ask the owner (or webmaster) to remove the disclosed data.
[Remediation] Be sure to adjust your request to the recipients (hacktivism webmaster won’t behave as a press webmaster).
[Remediation] If it’s not possible to remove the disclosed data, provide a complete analysis to the Public Relations team and the management.
[Remediation] Monitor leaked documents spread on websites and social networks (FB, Twitter, etc) and Internet user’s comments or reactions.
[Remediation] Provide the elements to Humans Resources team to eventually file a complaint against the insider.
[Recovery] Objective: Restore the system to normal operations.
[Recovery] If a system has been compromised, restore it completely.
[Recovery] Eventually warn your employees or some local teams about the issue to raise awareness and increase security rules.
[Recovery] When situation comes back to normal, eventually remove the official communication.
[Containment] Don't do anything without the CISO/person in charge written agreement
[Containment] Involve people so they can assist on the incident (Humans Resources, legal, Public Relations and business management of the suspected insider)
[Containment] Make an Humans Resources manager meet with the suspected insider to discuss what have been found and what will happen(possible support from legal, technical and management)
[Containment] Lower suspected insider privileges
[Containment] Suspend all suspected insider's autohrization
[Containment] Suspend all suspected insider's remote access
[Containment] Seize all suspected insider's professional computing device
[Remediation] Take disciplinary action against the malicious employee (or terminate the contract) and remove all his/her credentials.
[Remediation] Delete all fictitious or fraudulent operations made by the insider
[Remediation] Review all programs or scripts made by the insider and remove all unnecessary codes

[Recovery] If the incident has not been made public yet, be sure to warn all the impacted stakeholders (customers, concerned partners …) and required authorities. This communication must be made by top management in case of huge impacts.
[Recovery] Eventually warn your employees or some local teams about the issue to raise awareness and increase security rules.
[Containment] Notify management team and ask for permission to patch.
[Containment] If the vulnerability is critical stop the service until it is patched.
[Remediation] If a patch is available for your configuration, test the patch on a test system not on production.
[Remediation] If no patch is available for your configuration, try to create a patch or workaround and test it on a test system not on production.
[Recovery] Apply the patch on production.
[Recovery] Start back the service if you stopped it.
[Recovery] Notify that the service is working back if you stopped it.
[Containment] Disconnect the compromised area from network
[Containment] Isolate the source of the attack
[Containment] Find acceptable mitigation for the current traffic with the business manager
[Containment] terminate evil connection or process
[Containment] Update Firewall/IDS/IPS Rules to block future attacks

[Containment] Apply a strategy of actions matching your needs (block exfiltration destination/create false documents with watermarking for proof of theft/restrict file access for confidential files ...)
[Containment] Log all actions / analisys in ticket
[Remediation] Using the analysis from containment to find communication channels of the attacker
[Remediation] If the source is an insider, notifiy Humans Resources and management so they take over
[Remediation] If the source is identified as an outsider, contact legal so they take over
[Remediation] Define the remediation process
[Remediation] Test the remediation process
[Recovery] Restore the system to nominal state
[Recovery] Reconnect the previously disconnected devices
[Containment] Disconnect all computers that have been detected as compromised from the network.
[Containment] If you cannot isolate the computer, disconnect/cancel the shared drives.
[Containment] Block traffic if the malware is connecting to suspicious unknown IP.
[Containment] Notify other users by mail, possibly add instructions.
[Containment] Send the undetected samples to your endpoint security provider.
[Containment] Send the uncategorized malicious URL, domain names and IP to your perimetric security provider.
[Remediation] Remove the binaries and the related registry entries (if any) from compromised profiles.
[Remediation] If the above step is not possible reimage the computer with a clean install.
[Recovery] 1. Update antivirus signatures for identified malicious binaries to be blocked.
[Recovery] 2. Ensure that no malicious binaries are present on the systems before reconnecting them.
[Recovery] 3. Ensure that the network traffic is back to normal.
[Recovery] 4. Restore user’s documents from backups.
[Recovery] 5. Take a new snapshot of the system.
[Containment] 	Spread the URL of the attack in case of a phishing website.
[Containment] 	Spread the fraudulent e-mail content on spam-reporting websites/partners.
[Containment] 	Communicate with your customers.
[Containment] 	Deploy the alert/warning page with information about the current phishing attack.
[Containment] 	Check the source-code of the phishing website.
[Containment] 	See where the data is exported: either to another web content you cannot access (a PHP script usually), or sent by e-mail to the fraudster.
[Containment] 	In case the graphics are taken from one of your own websites, you could change the graphics to display a "PHISHING WEBSITE" logo on the fraudster's page.
[Remediation] 	In case the fraudulent phishing pages are hosted on a compromised website, try to contact the owner of the website.
[Remediation] 	Explain clearly the fraud to the owner, so that he removes the fraudulent content.
[Remediation] 	Explain clearly the fraud to the owner, so that he makes all the upgrade to improves security so that the fraudster cannot come back using the same vulnerability.
[Remediation] 	Send e-mails to the contact addresses of the hosting company
[Remediation] 	Try to get someone on the phone from the hosting company, to speed things up.
[Remediation] 	Contact the e-mail hosting company to shut down the fraudulent accounts which receive the stolen credentials or credit card information
[Remediation] 	In case there is a redirection, also take down the redirection by contacting the company responsible for the service.
[Remediation] 	If the takedown is too slow, contact a local CERT in the involved country, which could help taking down the fraud.
[Recovery] 	Ensure that the fraudulent pages and/or e-mail address are down.
[Recovery] 	Keep monitoring the fraudulent URL. Sometimes a phishing website can reappear some hours later.
[Recovery] 	In case a redirection is used and not taken down, monitor it very closely.
[Recovery] 	At the end of a phishing campaign, remove the associated warning page from your website.
[Containment] Disconnect all computers that have been detected as compromised from the network
[Containment] If you cannot isolate the computer, disconnect/cancel the shared drives ( NET USE x: \\unc\path\ /DELETE )
[Containment] Block traffic to identified ransomware’s C&C
[Containment] Notify other users by mail, possibly add instructions
[Containment] Send the undetected samples to your endpoint security provider
[Containment] Send the uncategorized malicious URL, domain names and IP to your perimetric security provider
[Remediation] Remove the binaries and the related registry entries (if any) from compromised profiles (%ALLUSERSPROFILE% or %APPDATA%) and %SystemDrive%
[Remediation] If the above step is not possible reimage the computer with a clean install
[Recovery] 1. Update antivirus signatures for identified malicious binaries to be blocked
[Recovery] 2. Ensure that no malicious binaries are present on the systems before reconnecting them
[Recovery] 3. Ensure that the network traffic is back to normal
[Recovery] 4. Restore user’s documents from backups
[Recovery] 5. Take a new snapshot of the system
[Containment] Notify the management, legal and public relation team to make sure they are prepared to deal with a strong image impact.

[Containment] Depending on the information vector of the bad reputation (ex: fake news on social media or denigration from a competitor), report an abuse to the media platform or block the message / URI if it's on your own website / platform.
[Containment] Suspend the logical and physical credentials of the insider if the leakage has been confirmed to come from an insider.
[Containment] Involve communication and legal team before any action.
[Remediation] Commication team should publish a press release to refute / gainsay the slander / defamation.
[Recovery] If your image was severly impacted, launch a product or a good news to re-brand your reputation.
[Containment] Spread the fraudulent e-mail content on spam/fraud reporting websites/partners/tools.
[Containment] Communicate with your customers.
[Containment] Deploy the alert/warning page with information about the current scam attack if the brand is impacted.
[Containment] In case you are impacted several times a week, don't always deploy an alert/warning message but rather a very informative page about scam, to raise awareness.

[Remediation] In case there is a fraudulent web page related to the fraud, hosted on a compromised website, try to contact the owner of the website. Explain clearly the fraud to the owner, so that he takes appropriate actions: remove the fraudulent content, and most of all upgrade the security on it, so that the fraudster cannot come back using the same vulnerability.

[Remediation] In any case, also contact the hosting company of the website. Send e-mails to the contact addresses of the hosting company (generally there is an abuse@hostingcompany) then try to get someone on the phone, to speed things up.
[Remediation] Contact the e-mail hosting company to shut down the fraudulent account of the fraudster. Don't forget to send them a copy of the fraudulent e-mail.
[Remediation] In case you get no answer, or no action is taken, call back and send e-mails on a regular basis.
[Remediation] If the takedown is too slow, contact a local CERT in the involved country, which could help taking down the fraud, and explain them the difficulties you face.
[Recovery] Ensure that the fraudulent e-mail address has been shut down.
[Recovery] If there is any fraudulent website associated to the fraud, keep monitoring it.
[Recovery] At the end of a fraudulent scam campaign, remove the associated warning page from your website.
[Containment] User/Phone call : if the attacker urges you to give a phone number : give the "Red Phone Line" from your CERT/CSIRT with an invented name and call your CERT/CSIRT team to warn them
[Containment] User/Phone call : if the attacker put too much pressure on you, pretext a meeting and ask him to call back
[Containment] User/Phone call : if the attacker want to be transfered to someone, put him on hold, call your CERT/CSIRT and transfer them the call (after explaining)
[Containment] User/Mail : forward the mail to your security team (including headers as attached documents)

[Containment] CERT/Phone call : talk with the attacker and use one of these techniques : impersonate the target, slow down the conversation and make him do a mistake, or explain him the legal implication of his actions
[Containment] CERT/Phone Call : if the trap phone number has been used, "burn it" and create another one (and publish it in the directory)
[Containment] CERT/Mail : Collect as much information as possible on the mail address
[Containment] CERT : aggregate all social engineering attacks to visualize the scheme
[Remediation] Alert law enforcement and/or file a complaint
[Remediation] Discuss the probleme in circle of truth to know if the company is alone in this case
[Remediation] Threaten the attacker with legal actions if he can be identified
[Containment] Spread the fraudulent e-mail content on spam/fraud reporting websites/partners/tools.
[Containment] Communicate with your customers.
[Containment] Deploy the alert/warning page with information about the current scam attack if the brand is impacted.
[Containment] In case you are impacted several times a week, don’t always deploy an alert/warning message but rather a very informative page about scam, to raise awareness.

[Remediation] In case there is a fraudulent web page related to the fraud, hosted on a compromised website, try to contact the owner of the website. Explain clearly the fraud to the owner, so that he takes appropriate actions: remove the fraudulent content, and most of all upgrade the security on it, so that the fraudster cannot come back using the same vulnerability.

[Remediation] In any case, also contact the hosting company of the website. Send e-mails to the contact addresses of the hosting company (generally there is an abuse@hostingcompany) then try to get someone on the phone, to speed things up.
[Remediation] Contact the e-mail hosting company to shut down the fraudulent account of the fraudster. Don’t forget to send them a copy of the fraudulent e-mail.
[Remediation] In case you get no answer, or no action is taken, call back and send e-mails on a regular basis.
[Remediation] If the takedown is too slow, contact a local CERT in the involved country, which could help taking down the fraud, and explain them the difficulties you face.
[Recovery] Ensure that the fraudulent e-mail address has been shut down.
[Recovery] If there is any fraudulent website associated to the fraud, keep monitoring it.
[Recovery] At the end of a fraudulent scam campaign, remove the associated warning page from your website.
[Containment] Evaluate the impact of the trademark infringement (traffic redirection/spoofing/scamming/slander(badmouthing))
[Containment] Evaluate the visibility of the infringing : does it have a high visibility (search enging ranking / followers)
[Containment] Monitor domains for futur use of scamming or phishing

[Remediation] Domain Name : notify the domain owner or hosting service of the infringement and ask them to remove the content OR/AND deactivate the domaine or transfer it to you OR/AND ask them to redirect their domain to yours
[Remediation] Domain Name : If all fails, initiate a Uniform Domain-Name Dispute Resolution Policy procedure if you are empowered to do so, if not ask someone who is to do it
[Remediation] Social Network account : Contact the service provider, notify them about the infringement and ask them to either transfer the account to you or deactivate it
[Recovery] Domain : Ensure the domain is either down or redirected to your company
[Recovery] Keep monitoring the domains or accounts
[Recovery] Buy the domain as soon as it is available
[Containment] If the unavailability will last a long time, notify people that the service is unavailable.
[Containment] If you can put a spare server so notify people the new URI, IP or setting so they can switch and continue using teh service.
[Remediation] Your service, feature or server is unavailable, if you have redundancy but no auto-switching, switch manually.
[Remediation] If there is no redundancy but you have backup, then deploy backup on another server make it available.
[Recovery] Check the problem is resolved.
[Recovery] Notify people that you will shutdown the spare server and that the normal one will be working back.
[Recovery] Shutdown the spare server and make the normal one working back.

[Containment] Backup all important data from the compromised machine,if possible using a bit-by-bit physical copy of the whole hard disk on an external support. Also make a copy of the memory (RAM) of the system, which will be investigated if necessary.
[Containment] If the machine is not considered critical for the company and can be disconnected, shut the machine down.
[Containment] Offline investigations should be started right away if the identification step didn’t give any result, but the system is still suspected of being compromised.
[Containment] The analysis must find the files used by the attacker and recently modified.
[Containment] Analysis : Check log files on the machine.
[Containment] Check the perimeter security logs.
[Remediation] Temporary remove all accesses to the accounts involved in the incident, and remove all fraudulent files.
[Recovery] Change all the system’s accounts passwords
[Recovery] Check the integrity of the whole data stored on the system.
[Recovery] Restore all binaries which could have been changed (use a classic /usr, /bin, /sbin)

[Containment] Backup all data stored on the web server for forensic purposes and evidence collecting. The best practice here if applicable is to make a complete bit-by-bit copy of the hard-disk  containing the web server. This will be helpfull to recover deleted files

[Containment] Check your network architecture map. Verify that the vulnerability exploited by the attacker is not located somewhere else (Check the system on which the web server is running / Check other services running on that machine / Check the connections to other systems, which might be compromised)
[Containment] If the source of the attack is another system on the network, disconnect it if possible physically and investigate on it.

[Containment] Try to find evidences of every action of the attacker (how he got in the system) and patch the system. If required (complex issue and very important web server), deploy a temporary web server, up to date with its applications. It should offer the same content than the compomised web server or at least show another legitimate content such as _Temporary unavailable_. The best is to display a temporary static content, containing only html code. This prevent another infection in case the attacker has user vulnerability in the code.

[Remediation] Remove all altered content and replace it with the legitimate content, restored from earlier backup. Make sure this content is free from earlier backup. Make sure this content is free from vulnerabilities.

[Recovery] Change all user passwords, if the web server provides user-authentication, and you have evidence/reasons to think the passwords may have been compromised. This can require a large user communication.
[Recovery] If backup server has been used, restore the primary web server component as nominal server

[Containment]If the machine is considered critical for your company’s business activity and can’t be disconnected, backup all important data in case the hacker notices you’re investigating and starts deleting files.
[Containment]Also make a copy of the system’s memory for further analysis. (use tools such as Memoryze,win32dd etc.)
[Containment]If the machine is not considered critical for your company and can be disconnected, shut the machine down the hard way, removing its power plug.
[Containment]If it is a laptop with a battery on, just push the “off” button for some seconds until the computer switches off.
[Containment]Offline investigations should be started right away if the live analysis didn’t give any result, but the system should still be considered compromised.
[Containment]Make a physical copy (bit by bit) of the whole hard disk on an external storage support, using EnCase, X-Ways, or similar forensic tool (dd, ddrescue etc.).
[Containment]Try to find evidences of every action of the hacker:

[Containment]Find all files used by the attacker, including deleted files (use your forensic tools) and see what has been done with it or at least their functionality, in order to evaluate the threat.
[Containment]Check all files accessed recently.
[Containment]Inspect network shares to see if the malware has spread through it.

[Containment]More generally, try to find how the attacker got into the system. All leads should be considered. If no computer proof of the intrusion is found, never forget it could come from a physical access or a complicity/stealing of information from an employee.
[Containment]Apply fixes when applicable (operating system and applications), in case the attacker used a known vulnerability.
[Remediation]In case the system has been compromised:
[Remediation]Temporary remove all accesses to the accounts involved in the incident.
[Remediation]Remove all malicious files installed by the attacker

[Recovery]No matter how far the hacker has gone into the system and the knowledge you might have about the compromission, as long as the system has been penetrated, the best practice is to reinstall the system fully from original media and apply all fixes to the newly installed system.
[Recovery]In case this solution can’t be applied, you should:

[Recovery]Change all the system’s accounts passwords, and make your users do so in a secure way: they should use passwords with upper/lower case, special characters, numbers, and at least be 8 characters long.
[Recovery]Restore all files that could have been changed (Example: svchost.exe) by the attacker.
[Containment] 1. Disconnect the infected area from the Internet.
[Containment] 2. Isolate the infected area. Disconnect it from any network.
[Containment] 3. If business-critical traffic cannot be disconnected, allow it after ensuring that it cannot be an infection vector or find validated circumventions techniques.

[Containment] 4. Neutralize the propagation vectors. A propagation vector can be anything from network traffic to software flaw. Relevant countermeasures have to be applied (patch, traffic blocking, disable devices, etc.) For example, the following techniques can be used: patch deployment tools (WSUS), Windows GPO, Firewall rules, or Operational procedures.

[Containment] 5. Repeat steps 2 to 4 on each sub-area of the infected area until the worm stops spreading. If possible, monitor the infection using analysis tools (antivirus console, server logs, support calls).
[Remediation] 1. Identify tools and remediation methods. Define a disinfection process. It has to be validated by an external structure, like your CERT.
[Remediation] 2. Test the disinfection process and make sure that it properly works without damaging any service.
[Remediation] 3. Deploy the disinfection tools, like Windows WSUS, GPO, antivirus signature deployment, or manual disinfection.
[Recovery] 1. Reopen the network traffic that was used as a propagation method by the worm.
[Recovery] 2. Reconnect sub-areas together
[Recovery] 3. Reconnect the mobile laptops to the area
[Recovery] 4. Reconnect the area to your local network
[Recovery] 5. Reconnect the area to the Internet
